question: What is Marisol Belt (Terra Belt Beta)?
answer: The Marisol belt (Terra belt beta) is an asteroid belt in the Terra system. It circles the sun beyond the orbit of Gen (Terra IV). Although it has been actively mined for centuries, it remains rich in basic materials such as iron and carbon compounds.

answer: The Perseus is a large gunship manufactured by Roberts Space Industries (RSI). First developed in 2528 for the United Planets of Earth Navy (UPEN), it was used in blockades and security patrols, most notably the Incident at Red Ridge in 2529. It became a mainstay along the former Perry Line after Xi'an-Human First Contact in 2530. In 2863, it was retired from production at RSI. In 2946, Admiral Ernst Bishop witnessed an aging Perseus participate in Operation Mandrake and requested that an updated Perseus-class fleet be put into production. After the creation of the Militia Mobilization Initiative, RSI expanded development to include a civilian version. The new Perseus, equipped with modernized weapons and a redesigned lower deck, was released in 2950.

question: What is the First Jump Day?
answer: First Jump Day is a United Empire of Earth (UEE) holiday celebrated on 10 April that recognizes the day Nick Croshaw became the first Human to discover a jump point. In the mid-23rd century, spacecraft in the Sol system began to vanish without explanation in a region nicknamed the Neso Triangle. The mystery attracted multiple scientists and explorers interested in pinning down the reason behind the disappearances. After ten years studying the area, astrophysicist Nick Croshaw discovered and successfully navigated a jump tunnel via a personally-modified quantum drive and discovered a new planetary system. The system was named Croshaw in his honor. The holiday was established in 2380 after the formation of the United Nations of Earth (UNE) government. Many commemorate the day by traversing a jump or by searching for new jump points.
title: Galactapedia: First Jump Day

answer: Virgil I, nicknamed Cyrene, is the first planet from the sun of the Virgil system, located in Vanduul territory. The only terraforming candidate when the system was discovered, it was quickly turned into a beautiful and warm world with exceptionally fertile soil. It was on track to receive recognition from the United Empire of Earth(UEE) Senate until SEY 2732, when the Vanduul invaded the neighboring Tiber system and Cyrene was transformed into a military stronghold. When Tiber fell in 2736, the Vanduul immediately flooded into the system and launched an attack on Cyrene, dropping countless bombs and destroying nearly all life on the planet. Today, the atmosphere is poisonous, and the once warm environment is deep in nuclear winter.
question: What is Cyrene (Virgil I)?
title: Galactapedia: Cyrene (Virgil I)

question: What is the ICC Stellar Surveyors?
answer: The Stellar Surveyors are a group of people who work under the auspices of the Imperial Cartography Center (ICC) to examine and explore newly discovered worlds and other locations. Their work is essential to the United Empire of Earth (UEE) government in establishing maps and boundaries and in the discovery of any potential resources. Most Stellar Surveyors are invited to work for the ICC based on their skill and experience in the public and private sectors. The official motto of the group is “Charting the Way Ahead.”

answer: The Genesis system is a developing planetary system that consists of a G-type main sequence star, a mesoplanet, a terrestrial planet, an ice giant, and an asteroid belt. Many terraforming companies put in early bids with the United Empire of Earth (UEE) government, but were ultimately barred from developing the system when the Fair Chance Act was invoked after multiple intelligent species were detected on Genesis II's surface. The system's other two planets are situated on either side of the green band, and are poor candidates for terraformation.

question: What is the Leyland's Tortoise?
answer:
Leyland's Tortoise


Leyland’s tortoise is a species of tortoise indigenous to Earth (Sol III). They have glossy shells with minor color variation around the scutes and the edges of the shells. Extremely docile, they are kept as pets by Humans, especially long-haul spacers. Over-collection and habitat destruction have made them nearly extinct in the wild.

Description


Leyland’s tortoises have smooth, domed shells in shades of green, yellow, and brown. The shell is relatively smooth; even if the tortoise matured in harsh conditions, the shell shows little to no scute pyramiding. The edges of the shell flare out slightly at the sides. The plastron is usually yellow, with green edging where it connects to the shell. The back end of the plastron is indented in a V-shape, underneath which is a small, nubby tail. Each of the tortoise’s four legs ends with five claws.


Range and Behavior


The original habitat of Leyland’s tortoise was limited to the South American continent, along the Andes mountains and into the central rainforest. Due to habitat destruction, the only remaining wild breeding population of Leyland’s tortoise on Earth is found along the Amazon river in protected areas of rainforest. Attempts to establish Leyland’s tortoise on other planets have been met with limited success; Saisei (Centauri III) and Locke (Idris IV) both sustain minor Leyland’s tortoise populations. In 2875, conservationists attempted to introduce the tortoise to Lo (Corel III). However, Banu residents of the planet consumed it at an unsustainable rate. The population did not take hold.


The tortoises are foragers, most active in the late afternoon until sunset, with a smaller window of high activity from sunrise to midmorning. Seeds, greens, fruit, invertebrates, roots, grasses, and fungi form the bulk of the tortoise’s diet. Over 50% of its day is spent at rest in shared burrows with other tortoises. After consuming a large meal, a tortoise might rest, totally immobile, for up to a week at a time.


Pet Trade


Leyland’s tortoises are popular pets due to their docility, low-cost diet, long lifespan, and adaptability to varying conditions. They are easily kept aboard most spacecraft in roofless enclosures 2 meters wide, 2 meters long, and 50 centimeters high. Plenty of shady spots and heated areas should be provided along with shelter and water. Ideally, a tortoise should not be kept alone. It is recommended that owners choose companions of the same sex to discourage unintentional breeding.


Because the tortoise is nearly extinct in the wild, it is illegal to own one that has been captured instead of captively bred. Any person within the UEE found with a wild-caught Leyland’s tortoise in their possession is subject to fine and arrest.
title: Galactapedia: Leyland's Tortoise

question: Will there be multiple currencies, perhaps used by different races? If so, will there be any variation in the exchange rates between those currencies?
answer:
CR: Well … so starting out it’s just going to be the UEC. There most likely will be a currency for the Xi’an. Most likely be a currency for the Banu. But that’s a longer term aspect and you probably wouldn’t trade in it. So you would … basically everything would be translated to UEC and we would just trade from there. And then maybe down the road if we got more into “Hey, future expansions” - which by the way we have a huge amount of work already but we’ve talked long term about being able to play another race like the Xi’an and the Banu - in that case it would probably make sense that you would have currency for those particular races.

TZ: Yep.

CR: But until … while you’re playing Human you will trade in UEC and there’d be just a … basically a currency … just like now if I’m in dollars and I’m in Europe I can pay in my card in dollars even though they’re translating it from … exchange rate from Euros.

TZ: We likely wouldn’t have an identical translation mechanism everywhere which means for the more economically orientated players it presents some interesting opportunities in terms of arbitrage and things like that. It becomes a commodity like anything else to where the value is one thing here and it’s slightly different there and therefore you can basically accept a contract and transfer that value via whatever mechanics we come up with then ... you could make some money.

ER: Just to be clear this is a stretch goal this one.

TZ: Yeah.

ER: It’s not going to be any time soon.

question: How is the upgrade system going to work on ships? Say I have an Avenger, does each ship come with a level on the subsystems like it does on the Power Plant or weapons? Will each ship have different levels of targeting system, coolers etc...? Give us a brief rundown on them and how they might vary between variants. I would assume the Freelancer Mis might have a higher targeting system size than the Freelancer Max etc...
answer: Travis Day: This is something we already see, like the 300i lineup. The 325 has a better targeting computer so it'll lock onto targets quicker for its missiles etc. The Aurora LN has better cooling, so it'll dump heat (without a sump). We definitely do this on a default component basis. That said I think the question was also about whether we have a size 1,2,3 size CPU like we do shield generators etc, and to that I say absolutely. The idea is that the larger the CPU you have the more data it handles coming through in a given time. It may be that the avionics unit itself has a certain size, so you might be able to put a new motherboard or something with more slots for things like targetting computers etc, and how many slots that takes up etc. There will be a level of customisation under the hood that you'll be able to tweak and change. It is a bit odd that larger CPUs handle larger amounts of data etc, when in modern times CPUs are getting smaller and smaller.Darian Vorlick: We ignore Moore's Law.TD: Yes! Every 8 years OUR CPUs actually get slower.
title: 10 for the Producers: Episode 05 (2015.04.20)

question: Hey guys! Great show last week! With the new modular ship system coming, have the old upgrade slots been replaced by the new system? Or are they used more for system upgrades like CPU, sensors and cooling?
answer: Travis Day: This is actually a good thing you asked this question. There may-... it sounds like from the question there may be a little bit of a misconception about the modular system. If you remember back to say, the Cutlass and the... what did they call it? Did they call it "Cutlass-gate" or something like that? Anyways, the idea behind the modular system is you can already swap out coolers, avionics, motherboards, I mean that's something the system already supports. So the additional functionality of the modularity system is to swap out whole internal blocks, right - so the innards of the ship.Without saying too much about the variants for upcoming ships, what this allows you to do is, say if you have something that's a cargo bay you can... maybe on a variant it's a medical bay, or maybe on another variant... well, use the Cutlass example - maybe on another variant it's for transporting prisoners. With the modular system what it allows you to do is basically, if the ship's designed right and the internal architecture is designed right, you can remove out the cargo bay and swap it for the prisoner transport part. And then if you have larger and larger ships, like say up to an Idris, or a Javelin, or a Hull-C or something like that... or a Carrack for example had it's little modular bits... you can start removing whole rooms and replacing them with other rooms, so you can further customize the role and capability that your ship can perform. So it's not so much about items it's about whole parts of the-... not parts of the ship, but ROOMS of the ship - parts of the ships that can support, you know, multiple items inside them, or gameplay inside them. So that's the idea.Darian Vorlick: Another facet of that is, going back to the motherboard and CPU of a ship's computer, there's going to be modularity to a certain degree on those, such as a motherboard that can handle greater data throughput, or certain apps that you can get for the computer that can lock on to more targets, or has faster locking speed, or maybe have better infrared spectrum signature detection.TD: Yeah, and what he's saying is completely true, and one of the things that we actually have set up on all the ships right now are a separate targeting computer, a separate avionics computer, a separate CPU. And the CPU can best be thought of as your power plant for your ship, but for the data pipe. So the three pipes we have on the ship - it's the data pipe, which is powered by the CPU, the power pipe that's powered by the power plant, and the heat pipe which is not really powered by anything but is provided into by the weapons and anything else you have attached to the ship - engines, etc. So, yes, for example in 1.0 you'll see the Willis Ops custom targeting computer for example, allows you to dock more simultaneous targets in your... oh, Zane's going to kill me if I don't get this right... "target overview context pane". So, you know, decreased missile lock times... it's all these different kinds of behaviors that fall out of that system. And that's something that we have not-... we on the item manufacturing and design side, have not done a great job of showing off that system very well. You'll start to see it in 1.0, but as we start adding more and more options, and items and components, it'll become much more a part of everyday gameplay.
title: 10 for the Producers: Episode 02 (2014.12.29)

question: Do the devs that are building the PU consult with you regarding lore routinely? I found so many interesting things in the lore that I'm afraid that it will be fiction rather than fact as I travel through the systems I've read about.
answer: Dave Haddock: Yes.Will Weissbaum: Yeah, I mean every single piece of lore that we post (like, pretty much, like 95%!) is looked at by the design team in some aspect, to make sure that what we're writing matches what you'll be able to do. We don't want to be spinning tales and writing checks that we can't cash.DH: It's been-... We realized very early on that there was an instant connection between what we released as lore, and what you guys thought would be in the game. So we started to really tailor it to make sure that, at any given time, what we're releasing is at least inline with the spirit and the idea of what it ultimately would like to be in the game. Obviously the mechanics will shift and refine and stuff like that, but yeah, you know... the idea is that we're trying to emulate hopefully what the experience will be like. So some of the places that you see, you read about, will be places that you can visit. The characters that you read about will be characters that you can interact with, and that sort of thing.
title: Star Citizen - 10 For The Writers Episode 01

question: How do you envision two organizations going to war?How will they fight? What would they fight over?Can we make burning Mark Skelton's Golden Shirt of Artistic Power a stretch goal?
answer: Well I definitely like making burning the shirt a stretch goal, that's pretty cool. I say if we get to $50 million, we burn the gold shirt.But in terms of the two organizations going to war and how they would fight, I would think that an organization would declare that it would be hostile to the other organization and then essentially members of the organization, if they came across each other, would try and attack each other.Usually wars tend to happen over pieces of real estate, so we are trying to add persistent aspects to the game, like we've mentioned an asteroid base you can fight over, or a space station you can fight over, and I would think that probably some of the organizational conflict will be directly related to persistent pieces of real estate in the universe, where someone's trying to fight for control of a valuable mining operation or someone's trying to fight for control of a jump point, or something like that. So that's kind of where I think the conflict would evolve around.Obviously we have some stuff that we have to do in terms of the instancing because we can't have 2,000 people all in the same area at the same time. But I think we've got some pretty good answers for that. So that's kind of how I see organizations going to war.
title: 10 For the Chairman Episode 26. June 23rd, 2014

question: The Drake Herald's position as an information and data encryption ship makes it very interesting. However is this a niche PvE mission ship, or is there something more?How will the information and data aspects affect PvP in the persistent universe?
answer: So we're definitely making one the items of cargo you can carry, if you've got an information runner, is encrypted information.That actually can be pretty valuable in our universe because, in our universe there is no FTL communication.Basically communication happens at the speed the ship can travel or a radio wave can travel in system. So you're sort of limited between the combination of the speed of light when you're in system, and then whatever distance you jump when an information drone goes from one jump point to another jump point.Essentially the way your communication would go across the galaxy is, say I'm on Earth, I want a message to go to Terra. I would beam the message to the closest relay station near a jump point outside of Earth, and that relay station would receive that message at the speed of light. Then it would basically encrypt the data, put it in a drone, and put it in a jump point. On the other side, there would be a relay station that would then get it, beam it to the next relay station at the next jump point, and it would do that until it got to Terra.Obviously you need to encrypt your data as you're sending it through the jump point so other people can't see it. That's where the Drake Herald comes in, because in some cases, you may not want to even be beaming your information because you're afraid someone might actually decrypt it and get the information.So it's like delivering a really valuable hand written note, but in this case it's digital. So maybe even things like deeds to areas of land, or if someone is the first person to discover an area, you have to get the digitally signed document to the records bureau on Earth, and that's something an information runner would do.That's where I would see some of the PvP and organization stuff happening because we'll definitely have some mechanics where--This is the UEE, we're going to have some bureaucracy, you're going to have to have some information and data.And that information and data you won't always want to have blasted over the air waves. So sometimes you'll hire someone to take it. Also there will be cases where there are no relay stations. There are only relay station in the well developed part of space. But in the less developed frontier worlds, there won't be. You'll definitely need a spaceship to take the information.As something like the Drake Herald, that has all the data encrypt banks that will make it much safer when you're sending it. You may not want to send that information say on a Hornet or something because it hasn't got the computer systems and the shielding to save it from someone that's a data snooper.I definitely think there will be some play mechanics for organizations so owning, having title, trade, and all that stuff that will be based on information packets that get sent.So therefore I think the PvP, as well as the PvE, will be something you can do with the Drake Herald.
